(Deputy managing director) }} | launch_date = {{start date and age|7 September 1970}} | headquarters = [[Hanoi]], [[Vietnam]] | website = {{URL|http://vtv.vn/}} | former_names = '''Independent Television System''' (7 September 1970 – 4 July 1976)
'''Central Television''' (5 July 1976 – 30 April 1987)}} '''Vietnam Television''', or '''VTV''' ([[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]]: ''Đài Truyền hình Việt Nam''), is the national television broadcaster of [[Vietnam]]. ==History== The first television broadcast in Vietnam was in 1966 when the [[United States]] set up 2-channels (1-[[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]] and 1-[[English language|English]]) in [[Ho Chi Minh City|Saigon]] for the [[South Vietnam|Republic of Vietnam]]. Named [[Vietnam Television (1966–75)|Đài Truyền hình Việt Nam]] (Vietnam Television), the network operated until the [[fall of Saigon]]. VTV was established with technical assistance and training from [[Cuba]] on 6 September 1970, in [[Hanoi]], as a department of [[Voice of Vietnam]]. During the [[Vietnam War]] it broadcast intermittently from a mountainous region. After [[History of Vietnam#Aftermath of the Vietnam War and Reunification|reunification]] in 1975, the former US-run stations in the south became part of the national network, and broadcasting was extended to the entire country. [[Color television]] was experimented in 1978 and adopted the French [[SECAM]] standard and fully implemented in 1986.[http://vtv.vn/hoat-dong-vtv/gioi-thieu.htm Giới thiệu VTV - Đài Truyền Hình Việt Nam | VTV.VN] Vietnam Television became an official name on 30 April 1987. And by 1990, VTV viewers had two national TV channels to choose from as VTV2 was launched and that year switched to [[PAL]].[http://www.vtv.org.vn/en/ VTV Official Site - Overall] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060703170229/http://www.vtv.org.vn/en/ |date=3 July 2006 }}[http://www.vtv.org.vn/en/important.htm VTV Official Site - Milestones] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100127050950/http://www.vtv.org.vn/en/important.htm |date=27 January 2010 }} VTV's regional broadcasting centres are located in [[Ho Chi Minh City]], [[Huế]], [[Da Nang]], [[Phu Yen]], [[Nha Trang]], and [[Cần Thơ]]. Programming is relayed nationwide via a network of provincial and municipal television stations. There are transmitters in most outlying areas of the country. By 2003, more than 80% of all urban households owned a television set. The percentage was considerably less in rural areas, but even the most remote village cafe has a TV and [[VHS|video]] or [[DVD]] player.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} In addition, each major city and most of the 51 [[Provinces of Vietnam|provinces]] have their own television stations.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} ==Channels== VTV today has the following channels:[http://www.vtv.org.vn/en/channels.htm VTV Official site - Channel list] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110430032052/http://www.vtv.org.vn/en/channels.htm |date=30 April 2011 }}{{cite web|url=http://vtv6.vtv.vn/|title=VTV6 - Ban Thanh thiếu niên - Đài Truyền Hình Việt Nam|author=vtv6.vtv.vn|work=VTV6|accessdate=12 July 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://vietbao.vn/Xa-hoi/VTV-se-co-them-3-kenh-truyen-hinh-moi/30071096/157/|title=VTV sẽ có thêm 3 kênh truyền hình mới|publisher=|accessdate=12 July 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://vietbao.vn/The-gioi-giai-tri/Ra-mat-kenh-truyen-hinh-VTV9/70099616/416/|title=Ra mắt kênh truyền hình VTV9|publisher=|accessdate=12 July 2015}} * '''[[VTV1]]''': News and current affairs; broadcast 24 hours a day.{{cite web|url=http://www.vtv.vn/LichPS/Index|title=Lịch phát sóng - Lịch phát sóng truyền hình VTV - VTV.VN|work=Đài truyền hình Việt Nam|accessdate=12 July 2015}} VTV1 initially broadcast on 7 September 1970. An [[high-definition television|HD]] version of VTV1 was launched on 27 March 2014. * '''[[VTV2]]''': Science and technology; broadcast 24 hours a day. The channel also broadcasts Japanese and American cartoons (e.g: [[Pokémon]], [[Yo-kai Watch]], [[Disney Television Animation]] and [[Cartoon Network (Southeast Asia)|Cartoon Network]] animated series), [[China]] and [[South Korea]] TV series. VTV2 started transmission on 1 January 1990. An [[high-definition television|HD]] version of VTV2 was launched on 19 May 2015. * '''[[VTV3]]''': Entertainment and sports channel, broadcast 24 hours a day. VTV3 launched on 31 March 1996. An [[high-definition television|HD]] version of VTV3 was launched on 31 March 2013. This channel is a first channel in VTV to broadcast in High Definition. * '''[[VTV4]]''': An international channel launched in 1998, offering a best-of package of programming from VTV's domestic channels to [[Vietnamese people|Vietnamese]] worldwide, now available at Taiwan [[CHT MOD]] Channel 215 and Malaysia at [[ABNXcess]] Channel 311. An [[high-definition television|HD]] version of VTV4 was launched on 19 June 2015. * '''[[VTV5]]''': Serve the [[List of ethnic groups in Vietnam|ethnic minority communities in Vietnam]], broadcast 24 hours a day. VTV5 launched on 10 February 2002. An [[high-definition television|HD]] version of VTV5 was launched on 1 July 2015. * '''[[VTV6]]''': Youth and sports channel, broadcast 24 hours a day. VTV6 started from 8 locations in Vietnam on 29 April 2007. An [[high-definition television|HD]] version of VTV6 lanuched on October 2013 * '''[[VTV7]]''': Education channel, broadcast from 6:00 to 24:00. VTV7 and VTV7 HD launched on 1 January 2016. * '''[[VTV8]]''': a channel for Central and Highland region of Vietnam, broadcast 5 AM to midnight. VTV8 and VTV8 HD launched on 1 January 2016. * '''[[VTV9]]''': Southern-oriented channel, launched on 8 October 2007; HD simulcast launched on 28 August 2015. ===Defunct regional channels (5)=== *'''[[VTV Huế]]''' *'''[[VTV Đà Nẵng]]''' *'''[[VTV Phú Yên]]''' *'''[[VTV Cần Thơ 1]]''' *'''[[VTV Cần Thơ 2]]''' Since 2003, all the above channels are also available via satellite, digital terrestrial and digital cable networks across Vietnam. The VTV itself offers 15 pay TV channels through [[satellite television]] and [[digital cable]] which are called '''K+''' and '''VTVCab''', respectively, with channels such as [[Reuters]], [[ESPN]], [[Disney Channel]], [[Discovery Channel]], [[BBC]], [[HBO]] plus about 40 original channels. Changes to VTV regional channels were made on January 1, 2016. [[VTV Huế]], [[VTV Đà Nẵng]], and [[VTV Phú Yên]] ceased programming and became '''VTV8''', a specific channel for Central and Highland Regions of Vietnam. Both the ''old'' '''VTV9''' (which was only for Ho Chi Minh City and [[Southeast (Vietnam)|Southeast Vietnam]] regions) and [[VTV Cần Thơ 1]] (which was only for [[Cần Thơ City]] and [[Hậu Giang Province]]) merged to form the ''new'' '''VTV9''' for both southeast and southwest of Vietnam, while [[VTV Cần Thơ 2]] was renamed '''VTV5 Tây Nam Bộ''', a bilingual Khmer-Vietnamese channel and the first regional variation of VTV5. On October 17 2016, '''VTV5 Tây Nguyên''', a channel for ethnic minorities in Central Highlands of Vietnam and another regional variation of VTV5, was also launched. ===Future channels=== * '''VTV24''': Not to be confused with VTV's news department. It will be Vietnam's first 24/7 newschannel, starts broadcasting somewhere around 4/2017. * '''VTV4k''': a new entertainment channel, together with current VTV3. VTV4k will be in [[ultra high definition]] ([[4K resolution]]) and will be on air from the first quarter of 2017.[http://vietnamnet.vn/vn/giai-tri/281391/vtv3-sap-het-doc-quyen.html "VTV3 sắp hết độc quyền"] * '''VTV7 Kids''', '''VTV7 English''' and '''VTV7 News''' will be on air in 2020. * '''VTV World''' will be the successor channel to the now-airing VTV4 as the new official Foreign Affairs channel of the government of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam.[http://www.chinhphu.vn/portal/page/portal/chinhphu/congdan/DuThaoVanBan?_piref135_27935_135_27927_27927.mode=detail&_piref135_27935_135_27927_27927.id=643 "Phê duyệt Quy hoạch phát thanh, truyền hình đối ngoại đến năm 2020"] * After the launching of VTV5 Tây Nguyên on 17 October 2016, '''VTV5 Tây Bắc''', along with '''VTV5 Miền Trung''' and '''VTV5 Đông Nam Bộ''' will also be launched as other regional variations of VTV5. == List of VTV channels on VTVcab == {| class="toccolours sortable" border="1" cellpadding="3" style="border-collapse:collapse; font-size: 90%; text-align:center" |- ! EPG no. ! EPG name ! Channel name ! Channel type ! Availability ! Notes |- | 1 | VTV1 | [[VTV1]] | Free TV | {{Yes|Free-to-air}} | News and current affairs channel. Channel numbers 1 and 300 (non-HD). |-) | 2 | VTV2 | [[VTV2]] | Free TV | {{Yes|Free-to-air}} | Education and science channel. Channel numbers 2 and 303 (non-HD). |- | 3 | VTV3 | [[VTV3]] | Free TV | {{Yes|Free-to-air}} | Entertainment channel. Channel numbers 3 and 301 (non-HD). |- | 4 | VTV4 | [[VTV4]] | Free TV | {{Yes|Free-to-air}} | International channel. Channel numbers 4 and 304 (non-HD). |- | 5 | VTV5 | VTV5 | Free TV | {{Yes|Free-to-air}} | Channel for several [[List of ethnic groups in Vietnam|ethnic groups in Vietnam]]. Channel numbers 5 and 308 (Khmer-only, non-HD). |- | 6 | VTV6 | [[VTV6]] | Free TV | {{Yes|Free-to-air}} |Sport and youth channel |} There are also other VTV channels on VTVCab, which are not shown here. ==Programming== VTV has its own film production company, the Vietnam Television Film Centre (formerly Vietnam Television Film Company), or VFC, which makes [[Television movie|made-for-television movies]] and [[miniseries]]. However, only about 30% of the entertainment programming shown on VTV is made locally. The rest is imported and dubbed in Vietnamese. Shows include Korean and Chinese [[Soap opera|serial melodramas]], which are the mainstay of nightly programming on VTV3. Aside from news and current affairs programming, VTV1 devotes itself to orchestral concerts, ballets, traditional theatre, ethnic minority culture shows and films. Also, on Vietnamese New Year's Eve, VTV broadcasts some programmes and comedy show like Year's Last Afternoon, News Special, [[Gặp nhau cuối năm]], music concerts, and firework shows, until 2 or 1 am. ==VTV Worldwide Bureaux== As of 2018, VTV has 14 bureaux with stationed staff and correspondents at: * [[Vientiane]], [[Laos]] * [[Phnom Penh]], [[Cambodia]] * [[Singapore]] ([[ASEAN]] region) * [[Beijing]], [[China]] * [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]] * [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]] * [[Manila]], [[Philippines]] * [[Moscow]], [[Russia]] * [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]] ([[Europe]] region) * [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] (UK & Ireland area) * [[Abu Dhabi]], [[United Arab Emirates]] ([[Middle East]] region) * [[Washington, D.C.]], [[United States]] * [[New York City]], [[United States]] * [[Los Angeles]], [[United States]] ==Criticism and controversies== {{Overly detailed|section|date=June 2017}} VTV4 has been criticised by Vietnamese emigrees who find the channel's one-sided support of the one-party Communist state distressing and offensive.{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/12/01/1070127351359.html|title=Crunch time for SBS over Vietnamese news bulletin|publisher=|accessdate=12 July 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/12/19/1071337155787.html?from=storyrhs|title=Breaking the news at SBS|publisher=|accessdate=12 July 2015}} According to Thanh Niên News, on 28 February 2016, VTV admitted that it had used copyrighted content without permission in some of its programs, confirming that the violation has caused its YouTube channel to be blocked. On this day, VTV, was notified by YouTube that the video sharing website had received multiple third-party claims of copyright infringement regarding videos on its official YouTube page. The page was blocked the following morning. VTV then told local press that some of its editors used some footage they found online in their news and current affairs programs without asking permission of the copyright holders. The programs were then uploaded on the YouTube page. The case was exposed after Bui Minh Tuan, 35, reported to Google that VTV had repeatedly used his flycam videos, posted on his YouTube page named Yamaha Trung Ta, without seeking his permission. Tuan, who runs a motorcycle trading company in the central province of Quang Tri, told news website ICTNews he had spent a lot of time and money to produce the aerial videos capturing beautiful scenes across the country. He claimed that over the previous year he had sent many complaints to VTV, the Department of Copyright and the Ministry of Information and Communications to report around 20 copyright violations by VTV, but no response was received. Tuan decided to report the case to Google, the owner of YouTube. Since September he has reportedly filed three complaints. He told ICTNews he is not trying to seek damages and that he wants VTV to respect copyright laws. Tuan said VTV needs to make a public apology to him in a news program and hold a press conference on the matter.{{cite web|url=http://m.thanhniennews.com/society/national-network-vtv-admits-to-copyright-infringement-after-youtube-block-59820.html|title=National network VTV admits to copyright infringement after YouTube block|publisher= 3 March 2016|accessdate= 6 March 2016}} ==See also== * [[Cinema of Vietnam]] * [[Culture of Vietnam]] * [[Communications in Vietnam]] * [[Media of Vietnam]] * [[Đài Truyền hình Việt Nam|Vietnam Television channel 9]] * [[Ho Chi Minh City Television]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.vtv.vn/}} * [http://english.vtv.vn/ Official English Site] {{Government of Vietnam}} {{ASEAN TV}} {{Television in Asia}} [[Category:Government of Vietnam]] [[Category:Television in Vietnam]] [[Category:State media]] [[Category:Publicly funded broadcasters]] [[Category:Companies of Vietnam]]

{{Other uses|Wheel of death (disambiguation){{!}}Wheel of death}} [[File:Pirates of the Sky 35.jpg|thumb|250px|Wheel of Death performance at the New York State Fair in 2008]] The '''Wheel of Death''', in the context of acrobatic [[circus arts]], is a large rotating apparatus on which performers carry out synchronized acrobatic skills. The "wheel" is actually a large [[space frame]] beam with hooped tracks at either end, within which the performers can stand. As the performers run around on either the inside or outside of the hoops, the whole apparatus rotates. Performers also perform balancing skills with the wheel in a stationary position.
The Wheel of Death is said to have originated in America during the early 1930s and was also known as the '''Space Wheel'''. Some early versions were performed by a single artist and incorporated a counterbalance on the other end. Following fatal accidents, the apparatus fell out of favour for a time until it was re-introduced in the 1970s under the name ''Wheel of Death''.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.sabungee.co.za/wheel.htm |title = The Wheel of Death |publisher = G. A. Bungee |accessdate = 2007-11-06 }}</ref> For its 2007 touring edition, [[Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus|Ringling Bros.]] started using the name '''Wheel of Steel''', as the word ''death'' was not seen as family friendly from a [[public relations]] perspective.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/30/arts/30circ.html | work=The New York Times | title=With the Greatest of Ease | first=Glenn | last=Collins | date=2007-03-30}}</ref>
Noted artists who have performed on the wheel include [[Nik Wallenda]], [[Elvin Bale]] and [[Bello Nock]].
The Wheel Of Death is also used on modern cruise ferries such as M/S Silja Symphony and M/S Silja Serenade owned by Tallink Silja Line.

The annual '''World Pie Eating Championship''' is usually held at ''Harry's Bar'' on Wallgate, [[Wigan]], [[Greater Manchester]], [[England]]. The competition has been held since 1992. In November 2006, a vegetarian version was added<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/food/Story/0,,1955147,00.html|title=Pie-eating championship goes slimline|work=guardian.co.uk|date=23 November 2006|location=London|publisher=Guardian News and Media}}</ref> after "relentless pressure", from [[The Vegetarian Society]]'s Keith Lorraine and Phil English.<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/manchester/7142115.stm|title=Dog jeopardises pie championships|date=13 December 2007|work=BBC News}}</ref>
In December 2006, in the competition, the [[Meat and potato pie|meat and potato pies]] were all 12 cm (5 in) in diameter with a depth of 3.5 cm (1.5 in). In the separate vegetarian contest, the pies were 10 cm (4 in) by 3 cm (1.2 in).<ref name=men>{{cite news|url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/p/228879|title=Only one pie each at world title scoff|date=22 November 2006|work=Manchester Evening News|last=Rooth|first=Ben|publisher=M.E.N. Media}}</ref> In December 2007, in the competition, entries included a competitor's dog, Charlie, who had eaten twenty pies and damaged a further ten the night before the competition, nearly jeopardizing the event.<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk"/>
==Winners==
===1992=== Dave Smyth, a painter from [[Hindley, Greater Manchester|Hindley]], won the inaugural contest in 1992, when he ate four pies in three minutes.
===1995=== Dave Williams of [[Preston, Lancashire]].
===1998=== Scott Ormrod of Aspull, [[Wigan]], Greater Manchester, eleven pies in thirty minutes.
===2005=== Anthony "The Anaconda" Danson, a weight trainer from Lancashire, managed to eat seven pies in three minutes, setting a new record.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1505589/Pie-championship-is-a-piece-of-cake-for-The-Anaconda.html |title=Pie championship is a piece of cake for The Anaconda |author=Neil Tweedie |publisher=The Telegraph |date=16 December 2005 |accessdate=14 April 2010}}</ref>
===2006=== [[Matt Dunning]] ([[Australian Rugby Union]]).
===2007=== Adrian Frost (42) from [[Wigan]] who downed his pie in an record breaking 35.86 seconds <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wigantoday.net/video-archive/The-pie39s-the-limit-for.3591521.jp|title=The pie's the limit for Adrian|date=14 December 2007|publisher=wigantoday.net|accessdate=24 February 2009}}</ref>
===2008=== Fred Wyatt, a sixty one year old warehouse packer won the 2008 Championship, which was broadcast live on the internet by pie per view.<ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5g9LGRWxYwbBezg_HsTfLcgfUsDgg ]{{dead link|date=October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.morningadvertiser.co.uk/news.ma/article/81424 |title=World Pie Eating contest at Wigan pub |publisher=Morningadvertiser.co.uk |date=2008-12-03 |accessdate=2015-10-14}}</ref>
===2009=== Barry Rigby, a warehouseman won, eating a pie in forty five seconds.<ref name="guardian2009">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/dec/15/wigan-world-pie-eating-contest |title=World pie-eating contest leaves competitors choking |publisher=Guardian News and Media |date=15 December 2009 |accessdate=16 December 2009|last=Wainwright|first=Martin|location=London|work=guardian.co.uk}}</ref>
===2010=== Neil Collier, aged 42, won this contest, with a new World Record of 23.91 seconds.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wainwright|first1=Martin|title=World pie-eating competition sets new record|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/dec/15/world-pie-eating-competition-record|accessdate=7 January 2015|work=theguardian.com|publisher=Guardian News and Media|date=15 December 2010}}</ref>
===2011=== James Robinson, aged just 24, won, with a time of 23.49 seconds. He retired from the competition following this to focus on taking up the trade professionally.
===2012=== Martin Clare won, with a new record time of 22.53 secs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wigantoday.net/news/local/barry-regains-pie-crown-1-7012238 |title=Barry regains pie crown |publisher=Wigan Today |date=2014-12-18 |accessdate=2014-12-19}}</ref>
===2013=== Ian Coulton of Wigan took the title, albeit with the slowest winning time ever.
===2014=== Former champion Barry Rigby once again recorded the best time.<ref name="bbc2014">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-manchester-30538447 |title=World Pie Eating Championships: Humble pie for Wigan chef after pie mix-up |date=2014-12-18 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=2014-12-19}}</ref>
Callum eden won the title in 2016 with a shocking 6.72 pies in 7 minutes. He now holds the title of youngest championship within the UK.
===2016=== The reigning champion, Martin Appleton-Clare registered a record breaking third win to take the ''2016 Championship''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/food-drink-news/wigan-pie-eating-championships-2016-12349256 |title=Watch: World pie-eating champion's 'Usain Bolt' moment at Wigan competition |date=2016-12-20 |publisher=Manchester Evening News |author=Emily Heward |accessdate=2016-12-20}}</ref>
==Controversy==
===Imported pies=== In December 2005, controversy was caused, when pies were imported from nearby [[Farnworth]], [[Bolton]], and local Wigan pies were sidelined as it was believed they were substandard, resulting in a four-man strong protest, which included Lee Hartney of [[The Smith Street Band]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/food/story/0,,1668818,00.html|title=I ate all the pies|work=The Guardian|date=16 December 2005|last=Lewis|first=Paul|location=London}}</ref> In December 2009, a similar situation arose, with pies being sourced from [[Adlington, Lancashire|Adlington]].<ref name="guardian2009"/>
===Quantity to speed=== In November 2006, more controversy was caused, when the competition was changed (to meet government ''healthy eating'' guidelines) from the number of pies consumed in a given time, to the fastest time to consume a single pie.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/manchester/6175726.stm|title=Health drive hitting pie eaters|date=23 November 2006|work=BBC News}}</ref>
===Lack of stock=== In December 2007, controversy struck again for the third year running, when the competition actually ran out of pies before the competition had finished.{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}}
===Wrongly sized pies=== In December 2014, pies of the wrong size were delivered to the event, while the intended pies were sent to a nearby divorce party. The contestants competed with halved pies, but the results were nullified.<ref name="bbc2014"/> The head of the ''World Pie Eating Championship'' went to court on the television show ''[[Judge Rinder]]'' because of this, against the pie maker of the wrongly sized pies, but was awarded nothing.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/judge-rinders-latest-case-sees-7598373|title=Judge Rinder's latest case sees him rule on a disputed PIE-EATING competition|last=Armstrong|first=Jeremy|website=mirror|access-date=2016-04-11}}</ref>
This very article was featured as evidence in the episode, referred to as "an online encyclopaedia website" by [[Robert Rinder]]. Last names were removed however, to protect identities and possibly copyright issues.
==Background== Wiganers are proud to be called pie eaters, but the nickname is not thought to be because of their appetite for the delicacy. The name is said to date from the 1926 [[General Strike]], when Wigan miners were starved back to work, before their counterparts in surrounding towns and were forced to eat "[[humble pie]]".<ref name=men />

{{notability|Companies|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = Wyrd Miniatures | logo = | type = [[Limited liability company|Limited liability company (LLC)]] | industry = [[Miniature wargaming]] manufacturer | foundation = 2005 | location_city = 300 Townpark Dr NW, Kennesaw, near [[Woodstock, Georgia]] | location_country = United States | key_people = Nathan Caroland and Eric Johns | products = ''[[Malifaux]]'' | homepage = [http://www.wyrd-games.net/ www.wyrd-games.net] | footnotes = }}
'''Wyrd Miniatures''' produces a range of 32 mm metal and plastic miniatures, in several genres, for painters and gamers. Established and offering its first miniatures in 2005, the company is owned by Nathan Caroland and Eric Johns.<ref>[https://cgov.sos.state.ga.us/Account.aspx/ViewEntityData?entityId=410335 Georgia Secretary of State Corporations Division, entered 13.2.2013.]</ref> In 2009, Wyrd published its first game, [[Malifaux]], set in a dystopian city in a parallel world. In 2011 they introduced the board game [[Puppet-Wars]].<ref>[http://www.tabletopgamingnews.com/2011/08/18/49767/ Tabletop Gaming News announcement. Retrieved 13.2.2013.]</ref>
The first years the company focused on casting miniatures for the wargaming and miniature painting market. According to Eric Johns, it started with Nathan putting together a few fun minis after having gotten friendly with a sculptor. It was only in 2007 he and Nathan decided to push forward as a real company and started developing their own game rules to go with their miniatures line.<ref>[http://www.livingdice.com/2713/interview-eric-johns-of-wyrd-miniatures-publisher-of-malifaux/ Interview on Livingdice June 6, 2009, retrieved February 13, 2013.]</ref>
After the release of Malifaux in 2009, which incorporated most of the miniature range, came a time of rapid expansion, and in March 2011 the company moved for the second time in 16 months allegedly to accommodate its growth, settling into a larger office and warehouse facility.<ref>[http://www.tabletopgamingnews.com/2011/03/21/44934/ Press release on Tabletop Gaming News March 21, 2011.]</ref>
In 2012 the partnership with Ghost Studio led to Wyrd introducing a new line of plastic miniatures for Malifaux using an all-digital manufacturing workflow, the so-called Freeform 3D solution from [[Geomagic]]. According to Geomagic, their platform for designing organic shaped products can sculpt, texture or emboss products with detail and articulation that traditional geometric CAD solutions simply cannot handle.<ref>[http://geomagic.com/en/community/press-releases/as-gamers-descend-on-gen-con-2012-wyrd-miniatures-shows-the-not-/ Press release from Geomagic August 15, 2012.]</ref><ref>[http://www.plasticstoday.com/articles/additive-manufacturing-rapid-tooling-give-gamers-intricate-miniatures-fast-0822220123 Article on Platicstoday August 22, 2012]</ref>
